title: I owe $2000 credit card bill, now a law firm sue me in small claim court. I didn't know it til now and the court date is past.
question: I believe I lost the case by default already.
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Credit,Debt,Debt relief,Bankruptcy and debt,Criminal defense,Criminal arrest,Appealing a criminal conviction,Lawsuits and disputes,Summons and complaint,Appeals,Default judgment,Small claims court
answers:
You MIGHT be the perfect canidate for bankruptcy. I urge you to talk to a professional, most bankruptcy attorneys have free consultations. Transferring assets to avoid creditors can, among other things, cause problems if you file bankruptcy (and if you had little else, these cars would be exempt anyway).

Rob Taylor
www.affordableattorneysgroup.com

The first video on my website gives a quick overview of the options when sued on a credit card debt. Please see my blog postings, below, on your (1) next steps after being served with a summons and complaint for an unpaid debt and (2) options upon learning of a default judgment for money in Cal. Superior Court. I'd recommend either posting a new question with the details of the actual status of the case or contact an attorney for direct and confidential help. If you contact my office for a free consultation, please mention this posting on Avvo.

You will not be arrested. This is a civil matter, not a criminal act. However, I'd suggest you retain an attorney before you leave and stay in contact with that attorney, so that you can rest assured the matter is being resolved, because a delay of four weeks may be long enough that when you return (if nothing has been done) it may be too late to deal with this, other than to pay a judgment, which will also affect your credit.

Robert Stempler (please see DISCLAIMER below)
www.StopCollectionLawsuits.com
www.facebook.com/SoCalConsumerLawyer
Twitter: @RStempler

Small Claims matters are a one trial matters. If you were not served and you did not appear at the hearing, you may be able to appeal. When a Small Claims matter is appealed it is heard as a new trial by the Superior Court. You will not be arrested since this is not a criminal matter. I recommend you look into paperwork for filing an appeal to this matter if you were not properly notified and failed to appear.

This is not a criminal matter you cannot get arrested. The worst thing that could happen is your wages can be garnished and or you bank account can be seized. I strongly urge to to switch bank accounts to a small bank that you have never done business with before. A small credit union is best.
